There is no infix operator for `isequal` , so when I have missings, comparisons look a bit uglier.
I'm wondering if it would make sense to add e.g.  `≌` as an alias for `isequal` .

messages.text:
It took me ages to figure out that this is why some Latexify.jl tests fails on windows.
```julia
julia> raw"text\\"
"text\\"   # note two backslashes

julia> raw"text\\
text"
"text\\\\\r\ntext"   # four backslashes and windows line-ending 

julia> raw"text\\text
text"
"text\\\\text\n\text"   # four backslashes but linux line-ending```

elements.text: It took me ages to figure out that this is why some Latexify.jl tests fails on windows.

julia
julia> raw"text\\"
"text\\"   # note two backslashes

julia> raw"text\\
text"
"text\\\\\r\ntext"   # four backslashes and windows line-ending 

julia> raw"text\\text
text"
"text\\\\text\n\text"   # four backslashes but linux line-ending

messages.text: it’s whatever line ending is literally in the file / input

elements.text: it’s whatever line ending is literally in the file / input

messages.text: there’s an argument to be made for normalization, but that isn’t currently done

elements.text: there’s an argument to be made for normalization, but that isn’t currently done

messages.text: Well it's not only that though - the windows line ending is only kept if the linebreak follows directly after a backslash. Otherwise one gets `\n`.

elements.text: Well it's not only that though - the windows line ending is only kept if the linebreak follows directly after a backslash. Otherwise one gets
\n

messages.text: I found this video <https://youtu.be/3TqN_M1L4ts> and I was amazed that the first 40 min demo/explanation from Swift could have been almost a copy/paste from a Julia demo. Someone from the audience asked "Why Swift and not Julia?" and the explanation just sounded like BS to me (but of course I am biased). Chris Lattner says that Swift syntax is similar to python, which is true for those first 40 min ... after his explanation about compilers ... the code starts to become messy and less readable in my opinion. So ... I still don't understand why Swift was chosen for TF by Google and why they keep saying that Julia is less mature.

attachments.title: Lesson 13 (2019) - Basics of Swift for Deep Learning
attachments.fallback: YouTube Video: Lesson 13 (2019) - Basics of Swift for Deep Learning
attachments.video_html: <iframe width="400" height="225" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/3TqN_M1L4ts?feature=oembed&autoplay=1&iv_load_policy=3" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

elements.text: I found this video

and I was amazed that the first 40 min demo/explanation from Swift could have been almost a copy/paste from a Julia demo. Someone from the audience asked "Why Swift and not Julia?" and the explanation just sounded like BS to me (but of course I am biased). Chris Lattner says that Swift syntax is similar to python, which is true for those first 40 min ... after his explanation about compilers ... the code starts to become messy and less readable in my opinion. So ... I still don't understand why Swift was chosen for TF by Google and why they keep saying that Julia is less mature.

messages.text:
The use of `@pure` in base/irrationals.jl is pretty boarderline.
Its well outside what is allowed by the `@pure` functions can’t call generic functions.
It also is really boarderline on the rule that all inputs should be so constrained that only know methods should be called (not user defined able methods). It makes it if you say that user can’t define methods on `Rational{T}` for their own type `T`.

elements.text: The use of
@pure

in base/irrationals.jl is pretty boarderline.
Its well outside what is allowed by the
@pure

functions can’t call generic functions.
It also is really boarderline on the rule that all inputs should be so constrained that only know methods should be called (not user defined able methods). It makes it if you say that user can’t define methods on
Rational{T}
for their own type
T

messages.text:
Gripe: When you click the GitHub logo on <https://docs.julialang.org/en/v1/stdlib/Statistics/|https://docs.julialang.org/en/v1/stdlib/Statistics/>, it takes you to a 404 page. The cause of this is that Statistics.jl lives in an external repo (<https://github.com/JuliaLang/Statistics.jl|https://github.com/JuliaLang/Statistics.jl>) instead of the JuliaLang/julia repo.

I wonder if it would be possible to fix this GitHub link for stdlibs that live in external repos.

elements.text: Gripe: When you click the GitHub logo on
https://docs.julialang.org/en/v1/stdlib/Statistics/
, it takes you to a 404 page. The cause of this is that Statistics.jl lives in an external repo (
https://github.com/JuliaLang/Statistics.jl
) instead of the JuliaLang/julia repo.
I wonder if it would be possible to fix this GitHub link for stdlibs that live in external repos.

messages.text:
`Rational{T}` gripe, I just got bitten by:
```julia> Inf + Inf
Inf

julia> 1 // 0 + 1
1//0

julia> 1 + 1//0
1//0

julia> 1//0 + 1//0
ERROR: DivideError: integer division error
Stacktrace:
 [1] div at ./int.jl:260 [inlined]
 [2] divgcd at ./rational.jl:44 [inlined]
 [3] +(::Rational{Int64}, ::Rational{Int64}) at ./rational.jl:283
 [4] top-level scope at REPL[4]:1```
it's surprising to see a division error when trying to add numbers.

messages.text:
What the heck is going on here?

```julia> c
3×3 SparseMatrixCSC{Int64, Int64} with 3 stored entries:
 ⋅  ⋅  1
 ⋅  1  ⋅
 1  ⋅  ⋅

julia> c ./ 1
3×3 SparseMatrixCSC{Float64, Int64} with 3 stored entries:
  ⋅    ⋅   1.0
  ⋅   1.0   ⋅
 1.0   ⋅    ⋅

julia> c ./ [1 1 1]
3×3 SparseMatrixCSC{Float64, Int64} with 9 stored entries:
 0.0  0.0  1.0
 0.0  1.0  0.0
 1.0  0.0  0.0```

messages.text: :slack: :grapes: : It looks like Slack recently started adding a notification to the favicon appearing in the browser tab. This might be useful if I had a private message or reply to a thread I'm involved with, but it seems to appear whenever there is _any_ unread message, which is just a distraction. Any idea if that can be turned off?

messages.text:
there's only a few cases where you're supposed to indent. I think you misunderstood the enforced rules lol
Some notable ones: Let, Do, Where, and Case blocks
Everything else is whatever you want. Can add indents, remove them, whatever.

elements.text:
there's only a few cases where you're supposed to indent. I think you misunderstood the enforced rules lol

```julia> if false
           1
       else; if false
           2
       end end```

messages.text:
I don't get that sentiment. I see it often, but I don't understand what exactly they mean...
• Do they mean that Julia's JIT + big runtime is unacceptable for phones, systems software and games, so there must only be scientific computing left?
• Do they mean the ecosystem only have cool packages for science, so it's not worth learning?
• Do they mean the compiler is built to only do science stuff? (How would that even work)

elements.text: I don't get that sentiment. I see it often, but I don't understand what exactly they mean...
Do they mean that Julia's JIT + big runtime is unacceptable for phones, systems software and games, so there must only be scientific computing left?
Do they mean the ecosystem only have cool packages for science, so it's not worth learning?
Do they mean the compiler is built to only do science stuff? (How would that even work)

messages.text: I've heard fragments of all three.... along with the way code is organized (module system or misunderstanding MD)

messages.text:
I have just spotted:
```julia> sum(["a"])
"a"

julia> sum(("a",))
ERROR: MethodError: no method matching +(::String)```
and
```julia> sum([0xe1, 0x1f])
0x0000000000000100

julia> sum((0xe1, 0x1f))
0x00```
I am not sure if these inconsistencies are known (and if they should be reported)

messages.text:
While we now have `import Pipe as Pipe2` we don’t have `using Pipe as Pipe2` to load everything exported and rename the module itself.
I also would like `using Pipe as _`  to load everything exported but not define the module itself.

we don’t have

to load everything exported and rename the module itself.
I also would like
using Pipe as _
to load everything exported but not define the module itself.

messages.text:
```julia> versioninfo()
Julia Version 1.5.3
Commit 788b2c77c1 (2020-11-09 13:37 UTC)
Platform Info:
  OS: Linux (x86_64-pc-linux-gnu)
  CPU: AMD Ryzen 7 2700X Eight-Core Processor
  WORD_SIZE: 64
  LIBM: libopenlibm
  LLVM: libLLVM-9.0.1 (ORCJIT, znver1)

julia> ^(2,-3)
0.125

julia> b = -3; ^(2,b)
ERROR: DomainError with -3:
Cannot raise an integer x to a negative power -3.
Make x or -3 a float by adding a zero decimal (e.g., 2.0^-3 or 2^-3.0 instead of 2^-3), or write 1/x^3, float(x)^-3, x^float(-3) or (x//1)^-3
Stacktrace:
 [1] throw_domerr_powbysq(::Int64, ::Int64) at ./intfuncs.jl:228
 [2] power_by_squaring(::Int64, ::Int64) at ./intfuncs.jl:249
 [3] ^(::Int64, ::Int64) at ./intfuncs.jl:273
 [4] top-level scope at REPL[7]:1

julia> @less ^(2,-3)```
shows
```^(x::T, p::T) where {T<:Integer} = power_by_squaring(x,p)```
but
```julia> Base.power_by_squaring(2,-3)
ERROR: DomainError with -3:
Cannot raise an integer x to a negative power -3.
Make x or -3 a float by adding a zero decimal (e.g., 2.0^-3 or 2^-3.0 instead of 2^-3), or write 1/x^3, float(x)^-3, x^float(-3) or (x//1)^-3
Stacktrace:
 [1] throw_domerr_powbysq(::Int64, ::Int64) at ./intfuncs.jl:228
 [2] power_by_squaring(::Int64, ::Int64) at ./intfuncs.jl:249
 [3] top-level scope at REPL[9]:1```
What's happening here?

messages.text: Maybe there's a better way that I don't know about, but I often find it really inconvenient that @edit and edit need a real call / full signature to get me to the code, even if all methods are defined in the same place and it's just difficult to satisfy the requirements of edit quickly. It is currently impossible to inline a function call at an particular call sight. (Caller side inlining)

messages.text: I seem to recall "nothing" not being able to be printed pre 1.0 was pretty annoying but I can't remember why. Maybe the underlying issue is that Julia is not really committed to whether nothing is a null value or a legitimate value
